title: Dadri lynching: District Magistrate N P Singh addresses peace meeting between Hindus and Muslims; calls communal forces ‘desh-drohi’
text:
Dadri lynching: District Magistrate N P Singh addresses peace meeting between Hindus and Muslims; calls communal forces ‘desh-drohi’ By Mohammed Uzair Shaikh on October 8, 2015 at 9:02 AM Comments 
Dadri, Oct 8: In a bid to counter the rising influence of fringe elements in the communally sensitive region of Dadri, District Magistrate N P Singh called a meeting involving residents of Bisara and nearby villages. Addressing the peace conference, Singh expressed disappointment over the brutal murder of 50-year-old Mohammed Akhlaq and urged the youth to beware of the vicious trap prepared by communal forces. 
The District Magistrate announced that he would be visiting each and every village and address the youngsters between the age of 18 to 30. Terming it an ‘ideological surgery’, Singh said it is necessary to take such initiatives in order to protect the nation from those who want to divide it on the lines of religion. (ALSO READ: Narendra Modi a sensitive person, seized of Dadri lynching incident: BJP) 
“Don’t invite diseases and virus. They are bacteria and virus. I will not name any organisation. But any organisation that talks about dividing the nation, talks about dividing the society on religious lines…they are desh-drohi, not wise,” the DM added. 
Singh repeatedly urged those present in the peace meeting to stop paying heed to rumours and provocative appeals made by fringe groups. “If you give others the permission to set a fire, you will turn to ash. I want to make you aware of this,” he said. 
Expressing disgust over the actions of the frenzied mob, Singh said, “Do you want to take this country back to the Stone Age? If someone is committing a crime, I am not saying they should not be punished. But, you do not have the right to give punishments. (This right) is with the system that you have made. This is a democracy, the system is yours, no one else’s.” 
The meeting was attended by members of both Hindu and Muslim community. Akhlaq’s brothers Jan Mohammed and Afzal Saifi were also present along with Bisara village chief Sanjay Rana.
